acute pulmonary embolism.Description: Sudden blockage of one or more pulmonary arteries by a thrombus, usually from deep vein thrombosis.
acute pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, hemoptysis, tachycardia, syncope in massive PE
acute pulmonary embolism.Diagnosis: CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA), D-dimer, Wells criteria, echocardiography
acute pulmonary embolism.Medicines: Anticoagulants (DOACs: apixaban, rivaroxaban; LMWH, warfarin), systemic thrombolytics (alteplase), catheter-directed thrombolysis
acute pulmonary embolism.Prevention: Prophylactic anticoagulation in high-risk patients, early mobilization, compression devices
acute pulmonary embolism.Care: Monitoring for bleeding, oxygen therapy, assess for right ventricular strain, consider inferior vena cava filter in contraindications to anticoagulation

central pulmonary embolism.Description: Large thrombus located in main pulmonary arteries or lobar branches.
central pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Severe dyspnea, hypotension, syncope, right heart failure signs
central pulmonary embolism.Diagnosis: CTPA, echocardiogram (right ventricular dysfunction), elevated troponin/BNP
central pulmonary embolism.Medicines: Systemic thrombolytics (alteplase), anticoagulation, vasopressors if shock
central pulmonary embolism.Care: ICU monitoring, consider catheter-based thrombectomy or surgical embolectomy in high-risk cases

chronic pulmonary embolism.Description: Organized thrombi in pulmonary arteries persisting >3 months, leading to vascular remodeling.
chronic pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, right heart failure signs over time
chronic pulmonary embolism.Diagnosis: CTPA (webs, bands, organized thrombus), V/Q scan (mismatched defects), right heart catheterization
chronic pulmonary embolism.Medicines: Lifelong anticoagulation (warfarin preferred), diuretics for right heart failure
chronic pulmonary embolism.Prevention: Adequate treatment of acute PE to prevent chronicity
chronic pulmonary embolism.Care: Evaluate for CTEPH, consider pulmonary thromboendarterectomy if operable, balloon pulmonary angioplasty

chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Description: Pulmonary hypertension due to unresolved chronic thromboembolic material causing vascular obstruction/remodeling.
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Symptoms: Progressive dyspnea, fatigue, syncope, right heart failure signs
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Diagnosis: V/Q scan (gold standard for screening), right heart catheterization, CT pulmonary angiography, pulmonary angiogram
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Medicines: Riociguat (soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator), anticoagulation, diuretics
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Prevention: Adequate anticoagulation for acute PE, early detection
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hyperte.Care: Evaluate for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (curative), balloon pulmonary angioplasty for inoperable cases, lung transplantation

in situ pulmonary artery thrombosis.Description: Thrombus formation within pulmonary arteries without embolism, often in pulmonary hypertension, vasculitis, or local inflammation.
in situ pulmonary artery thrombosis.Symptoms: Dyspnea, hemoptysis, signs of pulmonary hypertension
in situ pulmonary artery thrombosis.Diagnosis: CTPA (thrombus adherent to vessel wall), D-dimer may be elevated
in situ pulmonary artery thrombosis.Care: Similar to chronic PE/CTEPH management, consider immunosuppressants if vasculitis

normal (pulmonary arteries – pulmonary e.Description: No filling defects in pulmonary arteries, ruling out acute or chronic PE.
normal (pulmonary arteries – pulmonary e.Care: Consider alternative causes of symptoms (e.g., COPD, pneumonia, heart failure)

pulmonary infarction.Description: Necrosis of lung tissue due to occlusion of pulmonary artery branches, often with pleural-based wedge-shaped opacity.
pulmonary infarction.Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, fever, cough
pulmonary infarction.Diagnosis: CTPA (wedge-shaped peripheral consolidation with central lucency - 'feeding vessel sign')
pulmonary infarction.Medicines: Anticoagulation, analgesia, treat underlying infection if present
pulmonary infarction.Care: Monitor for resolution, may leave scar (linear atelectasis)

recurrent pulmonary embolism.Description: New pulmonary embolism after a course of anticoagulation or within 3 months of stopping therapy.
recurrent pulmonary embolism.Diagnosis: CTPA showing new filling defect, increased D-dimer after stopping anticoagulation
recurrent pulmonary embolism.Prevention: Extended anticoagulation after first unprovoked PE, evaluate for hypercoagulable state
recurrent pulmonary embolism.Care: Assess for non-adherence, malignancy, antiphospholipid syndrome, consider IVC filter if contraindication to anticoagulation

saddle pulmonary embolism.Description: Large thrombus straddling the bifurcation of main pulmonary artery, life-threatening emergency.
saddle pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Syncope, severe dyspnea, hypotension, cardiac arrest
saddle pulmonary embolism.Care: ICU, consider catheter-based embolectomy or surgical embolectomy if thrombolysis contraindicated/failed

segmental pulmonary embolism.Medicines: Anticoagulation (DOACs first-line), consider thrombolysis if hemodynamic compromise
segmental pulmonary embolism.Care: Hospitalization for initiation of anticoagulation, assess for right ventricular strain

subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Description: Blood clot in the smaller, more distal branches of the pulmonary arteries.
subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Often asymptomatic or mild symptoms like shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, cough, sometimes hemoptysis
subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Diagnosis: CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA), ventilation-perfusion scan, D-dimer
subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Medicines: Anticoagulants (DOACs, LMWH, warfarin), thrombolytics in severe cases
subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Prevention: Early ambulation post-surgery, compression stockings, anticoagulation in high-risk patients
subsegmental pulmonary embolism.Care: Monitoring for bleeding on anticoagulants, follow-up imaging, assess for underlying hypercoagulable state

brain edema.Description: Accumulation of fluid within brain tissue leading to increased intracranial pressure.
brain edema.Symptoms: Headache, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness, seizures, focal neurological deficits
brain edema.Medicines: Mannitol, hypertonic saline, corticosteroids (vasogenic edema), furosemide
brain edema.Prevention: Manage underlying causes (stroke, trauma, infection), avoid hyponatremia
brain edema.Care: Elevate head of bed, maintain euvolemia, neurocritical care monitoring, consider decompressive craniectomy

cerebral contusion.Description: Bruising of brain tissue from traumatic acceleration-deceleration or direct impact.
cerebral contusion.Symptoms: Altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, headache
cerebral contusion.Diagnosis: CT brain (hyperdense areas without frank hemorrhage), MRI for detail
cerebral contusion.Care: Serial imaging to monitor for expansion/edema, neurocritical care, rehabilitation

cerebritis.Description: Early stage of brain infection/inflammation before abscess formation.
cerebritis.Symptoms: Fever, headache, focal neurological deficits, seizures, altered mental status
cerebritis.Diagnosis: MRI brain (T2/FLAIR hyperintensity with patchy enhancement), CSF analysis, blood cultures
cerebritis.Medicines: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin + third-gen cephalosporin ± metronidazole), antivirals if viral
cerebritis.Prevention: Prompt treatment of infections (sinus, dental, otogenic)
cerebritis.Care: ICU monitoring, seizure prophylaxis, serial imaging to monitor for abscess formation

Diffuse axonal injury (dai).Description: Widespread traumatic shearing of white matter axons due to rotational acceleration.
Diffuse axonal injury (dai).Symptoms: Immediate loss of consciousness, persistent vegetative state, cognitive deficits
Diffuse axonal injury (dai).Diagnosis: MRI brain (gradient-echo/SWI showing microhemorrhages, DTI for axon integrity)
Diffuse axonal injury (dai).Medicines: Neuroprotective measures, manage ICP, amantadine for arousal
Diffuse axonal injury (dai).Care: Multidisciplinary neurorehabilitation, seizure prophylaxis, long-term cognitive therapy

Early ischemic stroke.Description: Acute cerebral infarction due to arterial occlusion, within time window for reperfusion therapy.
Early ischemic stroke.Symptoms: FAST symptoms (face droop, arm weakness, speech difficulty), vision loss, ataxia
Early ischemic stroke.Diagnosis: CT brain (rule out hemorrhage), CT perfusion, MRI DWI
Early ischemic stroke.Medicines: Alteplase (IV tPA) within 4.5 hours, tenecteplase, antiplatelets (aspirin/clopidogrel)
Early ischemic stroke.Prevention: Secondary prevention with antiplatelets, statins, risk factor control
Early ischemic stroke.Care: Stroke unit care, mechanical thrombectomy within 24 hours if large vessel occlusion, early rehabilitation

Encephalitis.Description: Inflammation of brain parenchyma, usually viral (HSV, arboviruses) or autoimmune.
Encephalitis.Symptoms: Fever, headache, altered mental status, seizures, focal deficits
Encephalitis.Diagnosis: MRI brain (T2/FLAIR hyperintensities), CSF PCR (HSV, VZV, etc.), autoantibody panels
Encephalitis.Medicines: Acyclovir (empiric for HSV), immunomodulators (steroids, IVIG, rituximab for autoimmune)
Encephalitis.Prevention: Vaccination (measles, mumps, rubella, Japanese encephalitis), mosquito control
Encephalitis.Care: ICU support, seizure control, rehabilitation, long-term neuropsychiatric follow-up

hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.Description: Global brain injury from cardiorespiratory arrest or severe hypotension.
hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.Diagnosis: CT brain (loss of gray-white differentiation), MRI (diffusion restriction in cortical/ deep gray nuclei), EEG
hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.Care: Neuroprognostication after 72 hours, multidisciplinary rehabilitation, palliative care consultation

lacunar infarct.Description: Small deep brain infarct (<15 mm) due to occlusion of penetrating arterioles, often from lipohyalinosis.
lacunar infarct.Symptoms: Pure motor stroke, pure sensory stroke, ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria-clumsy hand syndrome
lacunar infarct.Diagnosis: MRI brain (DWI positive, located in basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, internal capsule)
lacunar infarct.Medicines: Antiplatelets (aspirin, clopidogrel), intensive hypertension control, statins
lacunar infarct.Prevention: Aggressive blood pressure control, diabetes management, antiplatelet therapy
lacunar infarct.Care: Secondary stroke prevention, vascular risk factor control, rehabilitation

Metabolic encephalopathy.Description: Diffuse brain dysfunction due to systemic metabolic derangements (uremia, hepatic failure, electrolyte imbalances).
Metabolic encephalopathy.Symptoms: Altered mental status, asterixis (liver failure), myoclonus, seizures
Metabolic encephalopathy.Diagnosis: Clinical and lab findings (ammonia, BUN, electrolytes, glucose), EEG (triphasic waves), MRI often normal
Metabolic encephalopathy.Medicines: Treat underlying cause (lactulose for hepatic encephalopathy, dialysis for uremia)
Metabolic encephalopathy.Prevention: Manage chronic diseases (liver, kidney), avoid precipitating factors (infection, dehydration)
Metabolic encephalopathy.Care: ICU monitoring, correct metabolic abnormalities, supportive care

Neurocysticercosis.Description: Parasitic infection of CNS by larval stage of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm).
Neurocysticercosis.Diagnosis: MRI brain (cyst with scolex, enhancing lesions), serum/CSF antibody, exposure history
Neurocysticercosis.Prevention: Proper pork cooking, sanitation, treating intestinal tapeworm carriers
Neurocysticercosis.Care: Seizure management, shunt for hydrocephalus, long-term follow-up

Normal (brain parenchyma).Description: No acute intracranial abnormality, normal brain structure.
Normal (brain parenchyma).Care: No further neurological imaging needed unless clinical change

small metastatic brain lesions.Description: Multiple small intracranial metastases from systemic cancer.
small metastatic brain lesions.Symptoms: Headache, seizures, focal deficits, cognitive changes
small metastatic brain lesions.Diagnosis: MRI brain with contrast (multiple enhancing lesions at gray-white junction), systemic staging
small metastatic brain lesions.Care: Multidisciplinary neuro-oncology: consider stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) for limited lesions, whole brain radiotherapy for numerous lesions, surgical resection for dominant symptomatic lesion

small primary brain tumor.Description: Localized neoplasm originating from brain cells (e.g., glioma, meningioma) of small size.
small primary brain tumor.Symptoms: Seizures, headache, focal neurological deficits depending on location
small primary brain tumor.Diagnosis: MRI brain with contrast, MR spectroscopy, biopsy for histopathology
small primary brain tumor.Medicines: Corticosteroids for edema, antiepileptics if seizures
small primary brain tumor.Prevention: No known prevention for most primary brain tumors
small primary brain tumor.Care: Maximal safe surgical resection, adjuvant radiotherapy/temozolomide for high-grade gliomas, regular surveillance MRI

traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.Description: Synonymous with traumatic ICH; bleeding within brain tissue from trauma.
traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.Symptoms: Headache, vomiting, focal deficits, declining GCS
traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.Diagnosis: CT brain (hyperdense lesion in trauma context)
traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.Medicines: Reverse coagulopathy, manage ICP, antiepileptics prophylaxis
traumatic intraparenchymal hemorrhage.Care: Neurosurgical consultation, serial imaging to monitor expansion, surgical evacuation if significant mass effect or neurological deterioration

cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Description: Spontaneous lobar hemorrhage in elderly due to β-amyloid deposition in cerebral vessels.
cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Symptoms: Acute neurological deficits (depending on location), headache, seizures
cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Diagnosis: MRI brain (gradient-echo/SWI showing microbleeds), Boston criteria, often recurrent
cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Medicines: Blood pressure control (avoid excessive lowering), avoid anticoagulation/antiplatelets
cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Prevention: Control hypertension, avoid antithrombotic use unless strongly indicated
cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related intr.Care: Supportive care, seizure prophylaxis, neurosurgical consultation for large hematomas

cerebral contusion with hemorrhage.Description: Cerebral contusion associated with intraparenchymal bleeding.
cerebral contusion with hemorrhage.Symptoms: Similar to contusion but higher risk of mass effect and herniation
cerebral contusion with hemorrhage.Diagnosis: CT brain (mixed density lesion with hyperdense blood components)
cerebral contusion with hemorrhage.Medicines: As per contusion; manage coagulopathy if present
cerebral contusion with hemorrhage.Care: Close monitoring for expansion, ICP management, surgical evacuation if significant mass effect

chronic subdural hematoma.Description: Accumulation of blood products in subdural space >3 weeks old, often in elderly or anticoagulated.
chronic subdural hematoma.Symptoms: Headache, confusion, gait disturbance, focal deficits, may be insidious
chronic subdural hematoma.Diagnosis: CT brain (hypodense crescentic collection), MRI for equivocal cases
chronic subdural hematoma.Medicines: Manage anticoagulation reversal, atorvastatin (emerging evidence), tranexamic acid (trial)
chronic subdural hematoma.Prevention: Fall prevention in elderly, judicious antithrombotic use
chronic subdural hematoma.Care: Surgical evacuation (burr holes or craniotomy) if symptomatic, conservative with serial imaging if small/asymptomatic

coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Description: Intracranial bleeding due to impaired coagulation (anticoagulants, liver disease, hemophilia).
coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Symptoms: Acute neurological deficits, headache, altered consciousness
coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Diagnosis: CT brain, coagulation studies (INR, aPTT, factor assays), medication history
coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Medicines: Rapid reversal agents (vitamin K, PCC, idarucizumab for dabigatran, andexanet alfa for factor Xa inhibitors)
coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Prevention: Appropriate anticoagulant dosing, regular monitoring, avoid dual antiplatelet/anticoagulant combinations
coagulopathy-related intracranial hemorr.Care: Neurocritical care, hematology consultation, monitor for expansion, surgical intervention if indicated

diffuse axonal injury with hemorrhagic f.Description: DAI with additional punctate hemorrhages at gray-white junction/corpus callosum/brainstem.
diffuse axonal injury with hemorrhagic f.Symptoms: Similar to DAI but with higher acute morbidity
diffuse axonal injury with hemorrhagic f.Diagnosis: MRI brain (SWI highly sensitive for microbleeds)
diffuse axonal injury with hemorrhagic f.Care: Neurocritical care, early rehabilitation, monitor for secondary injury

early intracerebral hemorrhage (small ic.Description: Acute bleeding within brain parenchyma <6 hours, volume <30 mL.
early intracerebral hemorrhage (small ic.Symptoms: Focal deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, aphasia), headache, nausea
early intracerebral hemorrhage (small ic.Diagnosis: CT brain (hyperdense lesion), CTA to rule out underlying vascular lesion
early intracerebral hemorrhage (small ic.Medicines: Blood pressure control (target SBP <140 mmHg), reverse coagulopathy, avoid steroids
early intracerebral hemorrhage (small ic.Care: Neurocritical care monitoring, serial imaging to assess expansion, consider minimally invasive surgery

hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic s.Description: Secondary bleeding within an ischemic infarct, often after reperfusion therapy.
hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic s.Diagnosis: CT brain (new hyperdensity within infarcted area)
hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic s.Medicines: Reverse coagulopathy if present, control blood pressure, avoid antiplatelets temporarily
hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic s.Prevention: Careful patient selection for thrombolysis/thrombectomy, control hypertension
hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic s.Care: Close monitoring, neurosurgical consultation if large hematoma with mass effect

subacute subdural hematoma.Description: Subdural collection of blood products 1-3 weeks old, in transition from acute to chronic.
subacute subdural hematoma.Diagnosis: CT brain (isodense or mixed density crescentic collection), MRI for better delineation
subacute subdural hematoma.Care: Similar to chronic SDH; often surgical evacuation if symptomatic

traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage (tich.Description: Parenchymal brain bleeding due to direct trauma, often associated with contusions.
traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage (tich.Symptoms: Headache, vomiting, focal deficits, declining GCS
traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage (tich.Diagnosis: CT brain (hyperdense lesion in trauma context)
traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage (tich.Medicines: Reverse coagulopathy, manage ICP, antiepileptics prophylaxis
traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage (tich.Care: Neurosurgical consultation, serial imaging to monitor expansion, surgical evacuation if significant mass effect or neurological deterioration

adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Description: Pre-invasive non-small cell lung cancer limited to alveolar structures without stromal, vascular, or pleural invasion.
adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Symptoms: Typically asymptomatic, incidental finding on imaging
adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Diagnosis: CT chest, PET-CT, biopsy via VATS wedge resection (definitive)
adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Medicines: None specifically; surgical resection is curative
adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Prevention: Smoking cessation, radon exposure reduction, lung cancer screening in high-risk individuals
adenocarcinoma in situ (ais).Care: Surgical resection (segmentectomy/wedge resection), 5-year follow-up with CT surveillance, no adjuvant therapy needed

benign granuloma (healed tb, fungal).Description: Chronic inflammatory nodule composed of epithelioid histiocytes, often from prior infection.
benign granuloma (healed tb, fungal).Diagnosis: CT chest (calcified, stable small nodule), serial imaging showing stability
benign granuloma (healed tb, fungal).Prevention: Avoid endemic fungal areas, BCG vaccination for TB
benign granuloma (healed tb, fungal).Care: Annual CT follow-up for 2 years to confirm stability, no intervention needed

ground-glass nodule (ggn).Description: Focal hazy lung opacity not obscuring underlying structures, may represent pre-invasive/invasive adenocarcinoma or inflammation.
ground-glass nodule (ggn).Diagnosis: CT chest (persistent GGN), PET-CT often not helpful, biopsy via CT-guided or surgical
ground-glass nodule (ggn).Medicines: None for neoplastic GGN; antibiotics if inflammatory
ground-glass nodule (ggn).Care: Surveillance per Fleischner Society guidelines: persistent GGN >6 mm requires annual CT for 5 years, growth or solid component increase may warrant resection

minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (mia).Description: Solitary adenocarcinoma ≤3 cm with predominantly lepidic growth and ≤5 mm invasion.
minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (mia).Diagnosis: CT chest (part-solid nodule), definitive diagnosis after surgical resection
minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (mia).Care: Surgical resection (wedge/segmentectomy) with lymph node sampling, 5-year survival near 100%, no adjuvant chemo

normal (lung nodules – small lesions).Description: Incidental small lung nodules without malignant features, likely benign (granulomas, intrapulmonary lymph nodes).
normal (lung nodules – small lesions).Diagnosis: CT chest showing non-calcified nodule <6 mm in low-risk patient
normal (lung nodules – small lesions).Care: Follow Fleischner Society guidelines: low-risk patients with nodule <6 mm require no follow-up; 6-8 mm: CT at 6-12 months; >8 mm: CT at 3, 9, 24 months

part-solid lung nodule.Description: Lung nodule with both ground-glass and solid components, suspicious for invasive adenocarcinoma.
part-solid lung nodule.Diagnosis: CT chest, PET-CT (solid component may be FDG-avid), biopsy
part-solid lung nodule.Medicines: None for curative intent; surgery primary
part-solid lung nodule.Care: Management based on size and growth: >8 mm solid component suggests invasive cancer; resection with lobectomy preferred, adjuvant therapy if invasive

pulmonary metastatic nodules.Description: Multiple lung nodules from hematogenous spread of extrapulmonary primary cancer.
pulmonary metastatic nodules.Diagnosis: CT chest (multiple round nodules of varying sizes, often peripheral), biopsy to confirm origin
pulmonary metastatic nodules.Medicines: Chemotherapy/immunotherapy/targeted therapy based on primary cancer
pulmonary metastatic nodules.Prevention: Early detection and treatment of primary malignancy
pulmonary metastatic nodules.Care: Multidisciplinary oncology care, consider metastasectomy if oligometastatic, stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT)

pulmonary tuberculoma.Description: Granulomatous lung nodule due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, representing healed or active infection.
pulmonary tuberculoma.Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, may have cough, night sweats if active
pulmonary tuberculoma.Diagnosis: CT chest (calcified or non-calcified nodule), interferon-gamma release assay, sputum culture
pulmonary tuberculoma.Medicines: Active TB: multidrug therapy (isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol); latent TB: isoniazid prophylaxis
pulmonary tuberculoma.Prevention: BCG vaccination, treat latent TB infection
pulmonary tuberculoma.Care: Confirm diagnosis with biopsy if uncertain, treat if active, follow-up imaging to ensure stability

solitary pulmonary nodule (spn).Description: Single, well-defined lung nodule ≤3 cm surrounded by lung parenchyma.
solitary pulmonary nodule (spn).Diagnosis: CT chest, PET-CT for nodules >8 mm, biopsy (CT-guided or bronchoscopic)
solitary pulmonary nodule (spn).Care: Risk stratification using Brock/Pancost models; management based on probability of malignancy: low risk (<5%): surveillance CT; intermediate (5-65%): PET/biopsy; high (>65%): surgical resection

subsolid lung nodule.Description: Umbrella term for both pure ground-glass and part-solid nodules.
subsolid lung nodule.Care: Follow-up per Fleischner Society guidelines based on size and patient risk; persistent subsolid nodules may require long-term surveillance or resection if growth/solid component develops
